Comment: This is my first annotation of a chess match. This match shows that even if you are winning and about to checkmate, everything can turn around last minute. The final checkmate was pretty obvious, but I was quite oblivious. I always like to open with the king's pawn advancing two spaces
This move appears commonly, but I don't really understand the purpose of it.
Opening with a queen is not always a smart idea, but if the opponent is not careful, checkmate can be easy.
Another strange move I wasn't really sure about. The opponent must have been planning something.
Now if the opponent makes a silly move, the game is over.
However, this is not the case. The pawn blocks the bishop's attack, so I have to come up with another plan.
Releasing that pawn opens up my black square bishop.
That knight gets in my way, so I really need to change tactics.
I attack the knight with my pawn, hoping for it to go away.
It does. But what is he planning now?
Didn't really pay attention to it. My other pawn attack's my opponent's king pawn.
The bishop lines up an attack. I guess I can't take that pawn after all.
So I decide to attack the knight. He is getting pretty close and I'm beginning to get cautious.
He finally retreats. I feel safer.
So I move my pawn up so it reduces the chance of my opponent wanting to move his knight back, not that he would want to anyway.
The first piece of the game is taken. It was my queen pawn.
I take his bishop, but I won't stay ahead for long.
Of course, he would take me back.
So I take him, opening the attack on his rook.
He blocks me with a pawn forcing me to retreat.
